item.title: How to beat ransomware: Prevent, don't react
item.description:
How to beat ransomware: Prevent, don't react

Picture this: You've spent the last few weeks working on a tribute video for a friend's 30th wedding anniversary. You collected photos and video clips and edited them together, laying over a soundtrack of their favorite songs. It was a real labor of love.

item.title: Do I really need anti-malware for my Mac?
item.description:
Do I really need anti-malware for my Mac?

On the popular Discovery Channel program "Mythbusters," hosts Adam Savage and Jamie Hyneman take a legend and deconstruct it to see whether its long-held beliefs are legitimate. They've busted all kinds of myths, from Jimmy Hoffa being buried under Giants Stadium (not true) to the ability to kill someone without a trace using an ice bullet (the bullet vaporizes as soon as the trigger's pulled).

item.title: How to tell if you're infected with malware
item.description:
How to tell if you're infected with malware

Picture this: you start your computer and wait. And wait. And wait some more. When your desktop finally shows its face, things don't get any better. Your Internet is sluggish, your programs are taking forever to load, and your cursor is dragging 20 seconds behind your mouse.

item.title: Should you store your data in the cloud?
item.description:
Should you store your data in the cloud?

It's pretty simple to understand where a file goes when you save it on your PC. It lives on your hard drive, possibly housed in a set of folders you've created and organized yourself. That file is only stored on your computer, unless you decide to email it to yourself or save it on an external hard drive or USB.

item.title: How to protect your business from ransomware
item.description:
How to protect your business from ransomware

April 12, 2016 | BY Wendy Zamora Ransomware. So hot right now. Seems like everywhere you turn, there's another story about a new ransomware threat. Unfortunately, this trend in cybercrime is not going away. Now here's the bright side: As dangerous as ransomware can be, it's not insurmountable.
